comment: He's not very coherent. Asks rhetorical question after rhetorical question about irrelevant  implementation details without explaining anything relevant to the content or assignment. Seems too passionate about list sorting in Java.

Terrible professor. He grades in an extremely opinionated way. We did a group project and the one person in the group who did literally NOTHING for the project got the best grades out of all of us. NOTHING. Only likes teacher's pets. Reads from slides in monotone voice in his chair Failed me for the final just to bring me down a letter grade.
Ive taken Professor Gesick for SWE3313 and SWE4643, he was a great professor in both its why I chose him again for 3643
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Richard is an amazing professor. Whenever I found my self stuck Id email him and get very quick responses. He also is one of the fastest graders Ive ever had, I.E returning assignment grades within hours of submitting. He gave us lots of work to do but most of it was easy and brainless activities. I would take his class again.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Online Savvy

comment: Run.

His exams are all written response which leaves a lot of room for misunderstandings and opinionated grading.  His lectures are monotone and full of rhetorical questions. If you go by the book you're safe, research on your own time. You have to be really careful with planning for the project since most of it is just planning, start the code early.

Inconsistent with grading and doesn't provide much tools to learn the course content. The materials that he does  provide are usually outdated, but honestly, the entire department does the same thing. I would say, don't take this class, but he is the only one who teaches it and it's required for some majors/minors.

I took prof Gesick before for a CGDD class and it seems like he enjoys teaching those classes more as he was more active in our online class. With this one, he provides uploaded PowerPoints and readings bi-weekly and doesn't put too much effort into teaching this subject. Grades quickly and fairly. Quizzes are open note, same with final and midterm
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: The course in general sucks. Extremely dense instructions that limit creativity. Gesick cares but struggles to express it well. This course will teach you a lot about requirements elicitation, ask questions and just deal with him if he seems passive-aggressive. He's VERY lenient on grading, if you show effort you'll pass, it just isn't fun.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: I would avoid taking Gesick in person and online. It feels like he cannot teach a game design class and tried to delete a discussion post that I was trying to edit. He also gave me a bad attitude towards over asking simple questions. His assignments were vague and and first time I took the midterm, I failed each so bad I had to withdraw.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: I took this class in Fall 2020. He expected students to reach out to him for the project, which seemed unnecessary. If you did not, he took off points. Everything else was pretty much fine.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Prof Gesick is absolutely amazing! I failed the first 2 assignments pretty badly and on our last assignment, I emailed the professor for help. He answered his emails quickly, set up a teams meeting for us, and he helped me with the assigned; I passed the class because of it. Mandatory quizzes and discussions most weeks. No lock down for quizzes.

Don't, just don't. If you have any passion for game design this man will beat that out of you by attrition. Student participation doesn't exist in this class outside of assignment presentations and his attitude towards student questions ranges from causal dismissal to sarcastic non-answers. Not hard to pass but find a better option if available.

The best advice I can give to anyone who takes a class with this professor is to use his website (Google "rgesick1" since I can't paste URLs). There are code samples & videos for any class that are always relevant to the assignments and projects you have to do. You can also email him if you ever get stuck, he replies quickly and always helps.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: During the first week or two, I did like him. However, I quickly realized that all the information is super outdated (from 2008). Plus, his quizzes are complete BS questions that feel more like trick questions. He's petty/rude sometimes in his comments towards students. It feels like he doesn't care, and his grading and lectures reflect that a lot.

Professor Gesick is great. He really knows what he's talking about when it comes to game development, he genuinely cares about his students, and he always makes class entertaining. My only gripe is that sometimes his instructions are unclear or his materials are outdated. But if you talk to him about it, he will be glad to help out however he can.

The class was fine, but it seems like Prof. Gesick just doesn't care. For his online class, he never had a single lecture. Tests and assignments were just pulled from online. The group project always had little to do with what we learned in class. His grading is extremely petty. He will mark off points for requirements never stated. Overall poor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: Good Lecturer. There is a group project that may not be clear at times, but the professor is willing to help if you ask.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: We had a lot of grades in Gesick's class, so you had some room for mistakes. However, due dates were all over the place, tests sometimes had material we were never taught, and he would take points off of projects for things not on the rubric. It was frustrating but wasn't too much of a detriment to my grade. Work hard and you'll be fine.

I had him for a summer online class. Due dates were seemingly random & sometimes he would take points off for things not on the rubric, nothing terrible though. He was responsive to emails but example code & instructions were out of date. Midterm and final are worth way too much of your grade, but all the little grades help a lot if you do well.

This is possibally the most human professor you will ever have. This man will become a living inside joke for the mates you have class with. He is a very clear and direct person who gives some of the greatest feedback. I highly recommend him if you have average work ethics and desires to learn. I had no programming expierence going in.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Gesick is pretty good. I had prior programming experience going into the class so I didn't have too much difficulty figuring out what to do, but he may be tough if you don't know any programming already. He's got a clear rubric/syllabus and you know what's expected of you. Unity projects are a bit tough, as he doesn't give much guidance.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Tests are tough

comment: Gesick is a good teacher in my book. He helps you when you have problems with your code. Don't be afraid to ask him if you don't understand something.  Labs aren't that difficult and he has his lectures on his website for you to download them. I would take this course again if I felt like it.

Professor Gesick is a really good guy and is a good overall professor. His teaching methods are superb, and he is willing to help those who are struggling with programming. However, he is a harsh grader and will sometimes take points off of your assignments because of simple, easy to miss coding mistakes. Regardless, I'm happy to have had him.
He is quite clear during his lectures, but the tests are very hard and doesn't really like helping those who he doesn't know. The projects and homework can cause headaches.

Gesick is good at lecturing and explaining things, but is very arrogant and sarcastic and can make you feel belittled. He gives extra credit and will work with you if you need the help. Be sure to read the "free" course book and look at his code samples, they help A LOT. You will feel like you're teaching yourself more than him doing so.
He is nice to those who blend in, stern to those who don't.  Accepts -slightly- late work.  Gives you clear grading criteria that you must strictly follow to get an A.

Great guy and great teacher, respects that college students most likely have other things outside of his class and gives a moderate amount of work in response, and when you do turn in your projects and tests, he gives amazing feedback to help you learn. He's always willing to clarify further or help you outside of class, great professor.

Great Class. I do not 100% agree with some of his development techniques, but he respects that there is more than one way to code. He is very smart and he loves building others up. If you do not do the homework or the project you are not going to pass. The home work and the project were fun to anyone who wants to develop programs for a living.

If you're new to programming then it's a bit hard, but put forth a bit of effort and you can get an A. He actually reasons that you have OTHER classes and doesn't pile on the work. All of his lecture slides are online. He's willing to help with anything. He has an awesome moustache.
Very nice person. You have to study to pass. He asks questions in class to try to make things clear, but his questions are not very helpful sometimes. He gives extra credit and helps a lot.

Concepts are hard to grasp so don't miss lecture. Get a head start on the game projects as they take tons of time to debug. Ask questions and ask them soon. If you don't Gesick will move on, but if you do he will provide sufficient examples to clarify. Go to office hours if your stuck on anything and he will help you sort it out.

Some knowledge of computers and programming terms is recommended prior to this class. Gesick is a nice enough guy even though he plays like he is mean. Material is dense and the tests can be challenging. Ask a lot of questions because as soon as you learn a concept, it will become part of regular discussion. Don't procrastinate on projects!
He expect you to know about the course before you walk in the class, his lectures are not clear and confusing, pls dont take him.
Very hard if you have no experience in programming. Labs and assignments were sometimes time consuming. He is willing to help, but difficult to understand most times.
Take another professor if you are an asolute beginner. His course requires you to have some knowledge of programming.

Very good teacher. His lectures can be boring but he is very helpful and likes to joke around with the class. I didn't know anything about programming going into 1301 and I have a much better understanding of it at the start of my 1302 semester. He tells you what to study for on tests and gives you help on homework/games. Gesick is the best. :)

Once you understand the basics and pay attention to his lectures, he's quite good. Very helpful and not too eccentric. He tries to help you find solutions without telling you blind answers, which is the most important skill for any teacher. He also has a nice moustache, which will help you pay attention.
Was willing to work with me in getting things in and graded like 5 weeks late

he is not a bad professor.very helpful and he is there when you need help.for example,he stayed until 9:30pm to help two of his students finished their projects. i can honestly say that i have a better understanding of programming (conceptually) aftertakinghis class Iam not a programmer, not even closeTrying to beHe tells you what is on the test.

I came into his Java 1301 class with enough prior knowledge to never need to come to his lecture. As a person, he's a pretty nice guy, but his way of teaching wasn't what most students wanted. He would nudge people in the right direction without giving direct answers to try to help them find answers on their own. Difficult for beginners.

I took him for C# and and had no prior knowledge of programming. It was hard to take his class. It's more for people who already know how to program and wanna know more about it. Definitely not for people who don't know anything about the subject. He's a nice man and is willing to help you on projects and everything, just hard to do on your own.

If you've never done any programming (be it C#, Java, C+ or whatever) prior to taking this course, you will have a difficult time. Lectures are awfully dry and confusing and even when giving examples, material is still tough to understand. Labs are usually unclear and his tests are very tough. Honestly, just take someone else.

As a teacher, I find him hard to understand. When you can understand him, he is a very helpful teacher. His tests and assignments aren't terribly difficult though. I would recommend studying for this class if you haven't programmed before. Also, he sounds like Cpt. Kirk, which makes the class so much better.

C# game-based. I'm going to be straight up: if you have never coded before, you must really study hard for the A. or study some to get a B. I received a B. Let's just say i will never take programming again.

Absolutely one of my favorite professors. Funny, intelligent, and challenging. You will not be spoon fed (thank goodness), but he will give you all the help you need. Very good speaker and lecturer; the time flies by in his classroom.
A very good teacher, hard to understand at times but understanding and fair.
He is an okay professor, one of the hardest classes I took this year. He is extremely vague, and does expect to know some code before you take this class. Overall 3/5.

aggravated to death. This is my one and only programming class, and I have never programmed before. This guy wants you to know C# and syntax before you even walk in the class. Seriously take somebody else.

Ok teacher. Doesn't do a very good job of giving you clear help when you ask for it (he gives you hints, and hints don't help with syntax in coding). Sometimes the things he asks for in homework assignments are ridiculous, especially when he doesn't teach you how to properly utilize what hes giving you.
Is an Ex-Marine Pilot. Excellent Teacher! Always makes time for students even if help is needed on the weekends.
